reviewText:
Early Access Review

So the game starts with a tutorial, so far so good, although I still have no idea what to do after the tutorial is over. After this things are going down hill. In order to find out what to do next I decided to open the crafting menu, only to discover that almost all items have a placeholder text and the few that don't also don't show any stats or useful info.

Next you enter a world and start encountering enemies. Considering the bullets are almost invisible and there is no real feedback when you get damaged, you properly already lost half your health by the time you notice one is shooting at you. You decide to shoot back with invisible bullets, wondering if you hit the enemy, because they also don't show any feedback of being damaged. Not only that, but it also doesn't show how much health they have remaining or even how much damage you do. Eventually they disappear in thin air, because a death animation was too much work apparently.

Continuing with the mining aspect you notice that you are not the first person to enter the world. It seems the world was around already for a long time and all treasures have already been looted. Continuing to dig down or jumping down holes other dug for you, you notice that at some point you are unable to continue mining. As this is a 'crafting adventure game' it seems logical to craft a better pickaxe, but instead you have to level up your mining level. By mining a lot you ask? No, by killing monster, so you get a skill point once you level up.

This is the next problem in the game. You want to craft something with the ores you mined? A pickaxe? Level up tool making first. A weapon? Level up weapon making first. A bomb? Level up bomb making first. A healing potion? Even decoration? Yes, you get it, this is not a crafting game, but a leveling up game. Don't bother mining resources or hunting for treasure, just keep grinding monsters in this crappy combat system.

I stopped playing at this point, so I don't know how the building system is, but from what I heard you need to pay to make anything worthwhile. Which is the next problem: micro-transactions. But I guess you already realized that, considering this game is 'free to play'.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Firstly, I have experienced Deepworld for much much longer than it was on steam.

Admittedly, the Steam version is a bit shoddy. That's because the game was originally on Mac and iOS and is currently in the process of being ported to Windows. (I usually play on V2 Mac.) But if you check the updates, the V3 Steam version is slowly but constantly getting better, catching up to its v2 counterpart. Additionally, some of the microtransactions mentioned in negative reviews are on the way out. There's no more skill cap and now everyone gets unrestricted access to all biomes.

Anyway, I should tell a bit about what Deepworld is.
Deepworld is an online multiplayer sandbox game. A notable aspect is the fact that every single server/world is linked together via world teleporters. This makes it easy to travel between worlds, to go mining, exploring, questing, building, and so on. You can build something cool and show it to your friends or the public, or you can visit other people's creations. There's a place for everything.
The sandbox aspect means you can build whatever you can think of. Building materials are easy to aquire.

Remember: Deepworld is always in development. It will improve over time as more content is added to the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Deepworld - a Steampunk Terraria.
Pros
Attentive Developers - Support Service Active.
Unique Artstyle.
Easy-to-learn.
Early Access, which means many more updates!
Large playerbase.Cons
Highly Populated Servers.
Expensive Premium Items.
No Real Objectives or Quests.
Multilingual Servers, Partially Toxic Community.
Deepworld is a quick downloadable, sandbox game much like Terraria. If you're willing to put aside that it's Early Access and has microtransactions, you should give this game a try. It has a wide assortment of craftable items, as well as many worlds and materials that you can explore. If you're a fan of these games, I doubt Deepworld will get boring before the developers release updates.

As for the community, it can be a bit sketchy at times. As a crossplatform game, many of the mobile users of Deepworld don't use the chat. This lack of communication means that people ignore the fact that you're telling them to stop when they're mining the damn chair you just placed. If they're not ignoring you, they're probably speaking a different language, which is always bad when there are no dedicated servers for different locations.

Other than that, the tutorial doesn't give you much of an idea on what you should be doing, how to do things, or what materials are. I chalked it up to be trial-and-error and self-learning, but they could always use with a more descriptive tutorial for newer players. If this all sounds fine to you and you're willing to give it a chance, go ahead and give it a download.

Review is subject to change after Early Access and/or after more gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wall of text - TL;DR at the bottom

I would strongly recommend Deepworld to anyone who is a fan of the sandbox genre, and to anyone who likes steampunk, and to anyone in general. It's quirky artstyle and unique gameplay make it one of a kind in the sandbox genre

Whilst it may not have some of the features that other sandboxes have, Deepworld has its own unique gameplay, and has come a huge distance since I first started playing in early 2013. The game is still evolving, and its development heavily influenced by player suggestions.

Remember also before criticising the game too harshly, that this is an early access release, and there will be bugs.
Also, Premium is an extension of the game, and for only $3 is more than worth the cost given how much effort and time has been put into the game. I for one definitely prefer to pay a small amount of money, then be plagued by Game of War adds. Many people complain about pay to win games - almost every functional item in Deepworld can be looted, crafted, or traded for without spending a single cent.

Back to gameplay however...
If you like creating gigantic structures, and proudly displaying them, then Deepworld is a game for you.
As someone who has played the game for quite a long time, the engineering mechanics of Deepworld are limited solely by your imagination.
Want to build a massive password protected vault? You can (with enough creativity - although its a lot easier now than it was 2 years ago :P)
Want to build an epic parkour course? Do it!
Want to construct a PvE combat arena? You can!

Also addictive about the game is the looting system and the constant generation of new worlds, each full of new resources. Super rare items exist for all you collectors, and there is an ever expanding collection of craftable items.

The levelling mechanic reinforces Deepworld's RPG experience, with stat point allocations that makes every character unique. On top of this is the growing number of player customisation items.

Finally, there is a sense of immense satisfaction about looking around a world (Deepworld Server) at the end of the day, taking in that newly purified air and looking at the town that you rebuilt from ruins. That feeling, at least is why I play Deepworld. To create, restore, and exceed what has been previously done.

TL;DR:
Great mechanics and Unique art style
Only limited by imagination
Lots of items + super rare items
Endless sandbox
Levelling system makes character unique
Still in early release, so yes, bugs are a thing.

You might beg to differ, but Deepworld is my favourite game ever, and it's the one I keep coming back to.
Give it a go. Whilst you might find it takes time to get used to, keep at it, and it'll be an incredibly rewarding gaming experience.

I've been playing this game for almost a week now and I enjoy it.  Since it's been updated it really is free to play so you may want to ignore older reviews as I understand most of the game was locked in a previous version.

In this game you mine for resources and raid dungeons while fighting off various denizens of the Deepworld.   There is both melee and ranged (gun) combat.  It's design is basically steampunk which I'm usually not a fan of but it certainly works for this game.

You play the game in worlds which seem to spawn unexplored every hour or so, with different climates (biomes) to choose from.  Once you've chosen the world you want to explore, they give you a percentage of unexplored area before you choose, you are placed on the surface of the world which is fairly large.  I'd say it could take between five and ten minutes to run from one side of the world to the other.  If the world you chose is new and fairly unexplored you can expect there to be between twenty and thirty other players exploring and even then it's not hard to avoid everyone if that's what you want.

The other players may not be on steam as everyone, whatever device they're playing on all play together.   So they might have access to a game feature you don't have yet, since the game is new to steam.  For example bookmarking a world wasn't available on PC but today they released an update that added it.  So they are aware and seem to be actively improving the game.

Paying for features is an option still but just about everything you can pay for can be obtained by trading players who bought the items.  Like if you want to build a house, anyone can just come along and destroy it.  For a couple of dollars you can buy protectors that prevent anyone from destroying your stuff in a certain radius of the protector.

I'm level 18 right now and am still having fun, it's free and worth a try.

Early Access Review

It tried to be Terraria MMO, which is actally an interesting concept, but the execution was subpar.
I won't say much about the graphics. Personally I don't like it, but it's all a matter of taste.
More pressing issue is that everything else is also bad. Combat is janky. Exploring and crafting are arbitrarily locked behind paywalls (unless you want to grind levels for a long time,) and there is nothing to explore anyway. You'll be lucky if you find an area that was not already scrapped by other players (even though there are barely any players to begin with... or maybe I just log in at bad times? Who knows.) There are also premium areas, but obviously they are also locked behind paywall, so I have no idea what they look like.
And if you want to build something of your own, you better fork some money over for protection, otherwise if other players find your stuff, they'll break it apart and take it.
No matter how you look at it, you'll be much better off spending couple of bucks on Terraria, if you didn't already. (It's often on sale.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As it stands, this game strikes me as a lackluster 2D version of Minecraft. Crafting is limited to levels rather than resources, and even though it's an MMORPG there seems to be minimal player interaction. The enemies are all boring, easily-killed monsters and the excitement of digging through rock like in Minecraft is tarnished by the player's ability to see exactly where resources are. As such, it becomes more a chore to dig rather than a rewarding enterprise, for part of the appeal of digging is that hope that you'll find some more resources after the next block.

There's really no incentive to build things as far as I could tell, since your inventory pretty much holds whatever you find with no problems, and anything you build could just as easily be wrecked by another player unless you pay for a device that protects your blocks. Crafting is boring since every recipe is available for you to look at and, again, it becomes more a chore to create things than a rewarding enterprise.

As it stands, I really didn't enjoy this game. I didn't hate it, but after playing it for an hour I really didn't see any reason to go back to it.

Then, after all that, you can go Times Square to trade your items with other players! (Beware of spawnkillers placing bombs all over the place)

After all this you will probably have realized two things though:
- Premium Currency? Crowns?
- Premium!!?!?11!?!!!/1!??11

Yes, this game is freemium, and everybody that gets this game probably doesn't like that.

Well Premium is awesome, just read all these pros:
- It's only like 3 bucks - and it's permanent!
- You get access to way more items! This includes the awesome energy cannon.
- You can raise your skills higher! Want crafting lvl 4? Then this skill limit will be taken away when you upgrade!
- Plus more cool stuff!!

And here are the benifits to Crowns, the premium currency:
- Buy your own private worlds \(O_O)/
- Get packs to upgrade your abilities
- Exosuits!! Become over powered with the abilites of a FRIKIN CYBORG!!
- And even more cool crap to buy!

All in all, Deepworld is a fun game but you are limited without premium! (Which I highly recommend getting before they eventually raise the price)
I recommend that you try Deepworld for at least an hour or two.
Thanks for reading this very long review!
Hope you enjoy Deepworld as much as I do.

So, a couple things to keep in mind with this game. Number one is it is a free game, and number two it is a free game. These are two things you need to keep in mind when you go into this game, so your expectations should not be very high. Barring that in mind, I initially played this on mobile on my iPhone and seen there was a desktop version of this game. The game is the same on mobile and desktop. In fact, I think you possibly might even have some cross platform play going on. When I loaded the game on my PC and typed in the same name that I used on my iPhone it told me that name is already in use, so I had to create a second character (I didn't register it on my iPhone to my e-mail and create a password... doh).

Now actually playing the game. It's kind of like Terraria in a sense that it is a 2d side scrolling type of game. You start at level one, and collect lots of cool stuff and each time you mine something new you get bonus experience for that, so starting out the ultimate goal is to mine and collect as many unique items as possible and I thought that was pretty cool.

Mind you, I haven't gotten very far, but in the 20 minutes or so I spent playing the game I managed to do the following:

-Collect a pick axe.
-Collect a pistol.
-Meet up with real people and had conversation.
-Killed these metal flying things.
-Killed other cool monsters.
-Earned experience.
-Leveled up.
-Got killed by acid rain.
-Got killed by hunks of flying metal.

All in all, a pretty desirable first few minutes. I definitely plan to delve deeper into this game to see what it really offers. Like I said, it's a free game. It's not like we're spending extra money to play this game other than things and services we're already paid for (a working computer wit a keyboard and mouse and working internet connection), so if it turns out not being for you then at least you're not out of any money.

It'll be interesting to see what they add in this game in the future.

But, there are some reason that I have that make me feel this game could be one of the best. The skill bar is a fantastic idea, more unlockables and it makes the game more challenging and addictive! Different weather and environmental hazards such as acid rain keep you on your toes!

While I said this game was more of a hobby, I didn't mean a bad one.
